Table 1. Summary of datasets. The imbalance ratio ? is defined 
by ? = max k {n k }/min k {n k }, where n k is the number of sam-
ples in the k-th class.

Table 2. State-of-the-art comparison on CIFAR-100-LT 
dataset. Classification accuracy (%) for ResNet-32 architecture on 
CIFAR-100-LT with different imbalance ratios.  *  and  ? are from 
the original paper and [20], respectively.

Table 3. Comparison against baselines on CIFAR-100-LT (Im-
balance ratio = 100). Classification accuracy (%) of ResNet-32.

Table 4. State-of-the-art comparison on ImageNet-LT. Classi-
fication accuracy (%) of ResNet-50 with state-of-the-art methods 
trained for 90 or 100 epochs. " * " and " ?" denote the results are 
from the original papers, and

Table 5. Comparison against baselines on ImageNet-LT. Clas-
sification accuracy (%) of ResNet-50.

Table 6. Results on longer training epochs with Ran-
dAugment

Table 7. State-of-the-art comparison on iNaturalist2018. Clas-
sification accuracy (%) of ResNet-50 on iNaturalist2018. " * " and 
" ?" indicate the results from the original paper and [57], respec-
tively. RIDE [49] was trained for 100 epochs.

Table 8. Results on large architectures. Classification accuracy 
(%) of large backbone networks on iNaturalist 2018. The results 
are copied from [8].
Table 9. Comparison with CutMix using cross-entropy loss.

Table 10. Impact of different Q sampling distributions. Results 
on CIFAR-100-LT (imbalance ratio=100) according to different Q 
sampling probabilities.

Table 11. Ablation study. Results from variants of CMO with 
ResNet-32 on imbalanced CIFAR-100; imbalance ratio of 100.

Table 12. Data augmentation methods. Comparisons between 
augmentation methods for generating new minority samples on 
CIFAR-100-LT with an imbalance ratio of 100.

Table 14, 15 reveals that {BS + CMO} 
surpasses PaCo in most cases, and achieves a new state-of-the-art performance. These results demonstrate the effectiveness 
of CMO, despite its simplicity.
